brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a rule that checks for incorrect observer method definitions in CDI. The rule specifies that an observer method must contain only one @Observes parameter, cannot have parameters annotated with @Disposes, and cannot be annotated with @Inject and @Produces.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'incorrect-observer-method' checks all classes and their methods. If a method is annotated with '@Observes', it asserts that the method must have only one '@Observes' parameter, it should not have any parameter annotated with '@Disposes', and the method itself should not be annotated with '@Inject' and '@Produces'. If the method does not meet these conditions, it generates a message indicating the incorrect observer method and the class it belongs to.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://docs.jboss.org/weld/reference/latest/en-US/html/observers.html
Summary: This page from JBoss Weld documentation provides detailed information about observer methods in CDI. It explains how to declare an observer method and the usage of @Observes annotation.

2. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/java-ee-cdi
Summary: This tutorial from Baeldung explains the basics of CDI including the usage of @Inject, @Produces, and observer methods. It also provides examples of how to use these annotations in a Java EE application.
